Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by daddypix I ve gotten screened over the last few years and everything was fine.I ve developed urinary symptoms over the past year and last year had blood in my semen that went away so i didnt think much about it since my DRE/psa test were normal the previous 3 years.Now every since my exam ive had pain in that area between my anus n scrutum with an increase in symptoms, im hoping its psychosomatic. Im scheduled to see a urologist may 8.Dr google claims that its a 50% chance that its cancer.Has anyone had the new biomarker test using urine before getting a biopsy.or mri any suggestions on my approach or just follow dr. s protocol. im worried stiff that i ve had for 2 or 3 years and it just wasnt showing up on screening. I am not an MD, but my advice is to get a 3T MRI and a biopsy. If the URO you see has a lets watch this attitude, get a new URO.

Posts.Title: Wade on in and discuss fusion biopsy results with sir stressalot!

Posts.Content: In the hotel room 3 hours after surgery. A 930 am report time turned into a 1:30 surgery time. Dr Kaouk says I was procedure 40 since FDA approval last fall. Most pain is shoulder from gas and from catheter. Abdominal discomfort minimal. On some Percosets tonight. Dr. Kaouk hopeful things contained, waiting on pathology. Honestly guys I think Dr Kaouk may be best robotic urinary surgeon in US.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Very good, you're at the right kind of institution for such a new cutting edge surgery. Will you still need general anesthesia for the surgery? Is it quicker than the standard RALP? I hope you aren't shy, you'll probably be operated in a "stadium type" OR so a lot of residents and medical students can see. This is something new and even some experienced surgeons will be in the stands figuring this is something they've got to see. General anesthesia, still 3-4 hour surgery, and Yes I know the will have the equivalent of Jumbotrons set up in surgery.

Posts.Title: Nothing found on second biopsy.....now what?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by michaelcz Thanks everyone for the replies and guidance - I really appreciate it! This is one party I wish I were not invited to, yet that's life I suppose. The PSA dates were wrong - here's the list with the accurate years: 12/2017= 2.01 06/18/2018 = 2.62 09/05/2018 = 2.28 01/03/2019 = 3.12 01/07/2019 - 3.23 For what it is worth, the PSA tests were completed after the digital exams except for the 06/18 and 09/05 readings - I read that could add some to the total yet the trend certainly is upward here unfortunately. I feel decent about my urologist - he's out of Northwestern Hospital in Chicago. Also relieved that I was able to get in to see him next Wednesday to discuss the next steps. Notwithstanding the general unpleasantness of what I would expect from a biopsy and the risks of infection, I am leaning towards it especially if I can get the fusion guided one or under some sort of general sedation. I've got a lot of time on my hands now courtesy some recent job cuts at Xerox that trickled down to their subsidiaries where I worked (yea, it's been a GREAT 30 days here) so I suppose it makes sense to knock this out now. We'll see what he says next week and move ahead. Thanks again for all of the guidance guys. Just my experiance on the biopsy. Sedation is not needed. The procedure was totally painless, although I had a lot of anxiety. After the local wears off, I did have about 30 minutes were I felt ill and had local rental pain. Suggest you take a lidocaine product for you rear and some Aleve with you.
Posts.Title: New to this whole thing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by michaelcz Thanks everyone for the replies and guidance - I really appreciate it! This is one party I wish I were not invited to, yet that's life I suppose. The PSA dates were wrong - here's the list with the accurate years: 12/2017= 2.01 06/18/2018 = 2.62 09/05/2018 = 2.28 01/03/2019 = 3.12 01/07/2019 - 3.23 For what it is worth, the PSA tests were completed after the digital exams except for the 06/18 and 09/05 readings - I read that could add some to the total yet the trend certainly is upward here unfortunately. I feel decent about my urologist - he's out of Northwestern Hospital in Chicago. Also relieved that I was able to get in to see him next Wednesday to discuss the next steps. Notwithstanding the general unpleasantness of what I would expect from a biopsy and the risks of infection, I am leaning towards it especially if I can get the fusion guided one or under some sort of general sedation. I've got a lot of time on my hands now courtesy some recent job cuts at Xerox that trickled down to their subsidiaries where I worked (yea, it's been a GREAT 30 days here) so I suppose it makes sense to knock this out now. We'll see what he says next week and move ahead. Thanks again for all of the guidance guys. Just my experiance on the biopsy. Sedation is not needed. The procedure was totally painless, although I had a lot of anxiety. After the local wears off, I did have about 30 minutes were I felt ill and had local rental pain. Suggest you take a lidocaine product for you rear and some Aleve with you.
Posts.Title: New to this whole thing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IceStationZebra Post biopsy instructions say you might see blood for a “few days”. Today is the 11th day since my biopsy and I noticed I’m still shooting out small clots and brownish blood in the urine, which I’m not alarmed about. However the BM seem to be putting out a decent amount of bright red blood this morning. The toilet paper was basically bright red across the width and breadth of it. I got caught in traffic yesterday and really had to have a BM so I’m not sure If that extended pressure might have reopened the wounds from the biopsy. No temperature and I’m definitely not hemorrhaging or anything like that, just blood coming out as the bowels move. Problem to worry about or “meh, suck it up buttercup” I did not get brown blood until day 12 post biopsy. Blood from the other end I suspected were Hemmeroids. Treated with some AD ointment and it ended.

Posts.Title: Nanograms and Wish Me Luck Tomorrow

Posts.Content: I am 6 weeks post RALP. At first any time I stood or walked I was voiding. Very little leakage at night and I wear Depend underwear. At 4 weeks I could hold a small volume of urine when I go out of the car and headed directly to the bathroom. My URO told me I would see improvement about 6 week mark and he was correct. I was out and about today and used 2 pads over a nine hour period. For Pads, order some Prevail Guards (PV-811) from Amazon. They are far more absorbent than Depends Guards because they gel when wet. Depends underwear work nice to better hold the guards in place and protect from expected leaks when just off the cath.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Chronic dehydration? Begin measuring the amount of fluid you intake a day. I was subconsciously tempted to drink less to manage post RP incontinence. Over time it can become the new normal and then voila, you are chronically dehydrated. Something to check. Urine color should be the color of lemonade. Anything darker, say the color of apple juice, is dehydration. Which will show up a high chloride on blood results.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think you can have the capsule pierced without growth out of it. On the other hand, you can't have the opposite: EPE with the capsule intact. But I don't think the calculator checks for this. I believe the calc. results are without further treatment. As part of the RALP pre-surgery assessment they make the determination you will live 10 years without death from another health factor. That’s why ~70-75 is around the cut off age for RALP. But with a lot men living beyond the life expectancy, it makes you wonder.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic On the contrary, big pharma has no interest in compounds it can't patent. As a result, randomized, placebo-controlled, double blind studies of them are few. They have to be funded by the big univ. Institutes or governments, which are chronically short of research funds. Some of the hundreds of naturally occurring food substances that have shown in vitro action on disrupting PCa cells have shown results in human trials. I have heard your argument, but there are organic compounds patented as drugs.

As a result, randomized, placebo-controlled, double blind studies of them are few. They have to be funded by the big univ. Institutes or governments, which are chronically short of research funds. Some of the hundreds of naturally occurring food substances that have shown in vitro action on disrupting PCa cells have shown results in human trials. I have heard your argument, but there are organic compounds patented as drugs.

I was DX 75 days ago, guess those almonds are working.

Posts.Title: Today ... got my post-op pathology.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I can think of at least three reasons why radiation shouldn't be in consideration now. First of, your PSA is low. A number of FBs who use a 3-decimal uPSA test have been steady in this range for years. Secondly, your PSA isn't rising. Thirdly, you wouldn't know where to irradiate: even the most sophisticated scans aren't good at finding the location of lesions at this low a PSA level (prostate fossa? LN? bone?). I think my uro would agree that a <0.1 value would be a good place to start planning. That day might not come or could be years away when, technology and treatment has progressed even farther. Djin I believe they are considering ART due + margins and ECE while there is a good chance everything is still local.

Posts.Title: The Stumbling journey continues on to unknown destinations

Posts.Content: To answer your question about PT this early, I am keeping track of pads and fear I am actually losing continence. I have been vigantly doing keagels and rather than wasting months I want get to this under control as soon as possible. I am also heading to the pool next week to start to reduce a big belly. So if PT is an option, I can’t travel to CC for this and don’t know if they will prescribe into another facility. The other issue is my URO did not refer me to CC and I am done with that URO and wondering if I need another local URO.

Posts.Title: Integrating distant and local care

Posts.Content: According to the Decipher website, once they get the order they get the insurance approval. According to MyChart the specimen was processed a week after the order and it seems the insurance is not an issue. In a lot of ways I glad I have not had to deal with a Medicare Advantage or Gap plan. My insurance has been pretty good so far. Being a pT3 I don’t think there was a risk argument. A pT2 G9 shouldn’t have been a denial by BCBS in your case. Sad, but the insurance is playing an age game and the chances at age 69 of something else killing you before PCa.

AgeInfo.Phrase: and the chances at age 69 of something else killing you

Posts.Content: From what you have posted, it sounds like your GP and URO are competent doing what needs to be done. You have a lot of questions right now no one can answer. I know that is not very helpful, but you have to let the tests happen and to answer your questions. Hopefully if he does have cancer you will get a positive biopsy result and the Gleason Score can be determined. A negative result does not mean he does not have cancer as the samples taken can miss the tumors.

Posts.Content: To answer your question on insurance, if you are not Medicare or working / retired from a large govt agency or corporation, your options for in network care are going to be limited. If you are in an HMO plan, all your options will be very limited. If I had a G6 cancer, I would have been treated locally.

Posts.Title: New member, new worries.

Posts.Content: From what you have posted, it sounds like your GP and URO are competent doing what needs to be done. You have a lot of questions right now no one can answer. I know that is not very helpful, but you have to let the tests happen and to answer your questions. Hopefully if he does have cancer you will get a positive biopsy result and the Gleason Score can be determined. A negative result does not mean he does not have cancer as the samples taken can miss the tumors.

Posts.Title: Update and ED Question

Posts.Content: I am not trying to sway your treatment decisions, but one question you might want to ask about is incontinence after surgery. My URO advised me the big abdomens put stress on the bladder and cause long tern incontinence that may require additional surgery. I also have an acquaintance who is GS8 who had a very good outcome with Cryotherapy.

Posts.Title: Beginning Neoadjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joseywales The overall goal is to shrink the cancer prior to surgery to reduce the probability of positive margins. From what I've read, it may knock out any free floating cancer cells before they settle in and begin to grow. The left side of my prostate is 80% cancer and it 'abuts the capsule along almost the entire side. I would be very surprised if your pathology post RALP was your prostate was 80% involved by cancer. If you look at my signature, the left side on my biopsy looked like 100%. The pathology stated 10% of the prostate was involved. 5-35% is the range reported on this site with ~20% about the average.

Posts.Title: Beginning Neoadjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi there, gopher, Welcome to the forum. About half of prostatectomy patients have this problem after surgery, including myself. But it is usually only temporary as part of the healing process and goes away. I would think that yours should be cleared up by now, although I also wonder how many kegel exercises you are doing? My instructions from Mayo Clinic were to just do a total of SEVEN REPS per day -- and that too many reps can actually weaken the muscles. Let's see what others say..... What Kegels were they having you do? The instructions I have a a basic keakel 3 times a day from CC, but I saw a 7 position Kegel excercise in line that made a lot of sense. Standing, siting, rolling out of bed, ect.

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim Unless you are considering OSU, I would not be getting a second opinion here in Ohio. Not that our hospitals here are bad, but they are not top tier cancer centers.

Posts.Content: So I have seen a local Uro and a Cleveland Clinic Uro. The local Uro knows I have been to CC and who I have seen at CC when I arrive today for a some urinary issues and a consultation. Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs Radiation

Posts.Content: I am 4 weeks post catheter. Initially when I was out and about I had constant leakage and never had any urine to pass if I walked very far and my bladder was empty when I got to a bathroom. About 7 guards or shields a day. Most nights dry. Able to hold urine now with a few drips and spurts walking, but have urine in my bladder when I use the restroom. Down to 5 guards or shields a day, but much more active and consuming more liquids. Doing Ks at least 3x a day, but not doing them standing up was an early mistake. URO says things will be slow to improve first 6 weeks.

Posts.Title: Incontinence ... think I am doing okay.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Busby, you are a young man and your pathology was not that bad. It appears from your sig that the cause of your PSA is your positive margin and lymphoascular invasion. So there is likely some cancerous tissue remaining local to your prostate bed. My non-professional recommendation would be to treat it NOW before it leaves the pelvic area and moves on to other parts of your body. At that point it would become incurable, and you would be destined for lifelong HT, or a slow painful death. You are much too young for that. Hit this thing with everything available NOW to knock it out before it takes over. Good luck! You make some valid points and I do not advocate no treatment, but with the LVI is there is a reasonable possibility that things are not still regional. Going through RT with possible zero benefit will likely be the recommended treatment.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim Unless you are considering OSU, I would not be getting a second opinion here in Ohio. Not that our hospitals here are bad, but they are not top tier cancer centers.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim Unless you are considering OSU, I would not be getting a second opinion here in Ohio. Not that our hospitals here are bad, but they are not top tier cancer centers.

Posts.Title: Prognosis, do you believe your doctor?

Posts.Content: So I have seen a local Uro and a Cleveland Clinic Uro. The local Uro knows I have been to CC and who I have seen at CC when I arrive today for a some urinary issues and a consultation. He does a very good job explaining things lasting about an hour. I ask hm what he believed the odds of cure with surgery. The value given was 2x what I expected him to say based on my research. To some extent I believe I was getting a sales job. What are your experiances?
Posts.Title: Prognosis, do you believe your doctor?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Thanks for the heads up. They certainly spend a lot on TV ads. I don't see similar advertising levels from the major academic centers. With your promising negative bone scan and CTs, I hope your PCa proves to be prostate-confined. Djin Three points, with one 100% core I do not have much confidence in the PCa being confined. Within a 300 mi radius Cleveland runs ads, but that has no effect on my decision to go there. Cancer Centers still send me personalized emails marketing me to go there.

Posts.Title: 41 with a PIRADS-2/ PSA 3.5 14% free, and a ExoDx score of 51.71=High Grade Cancer?

Posts.Content: I am 4 weeks post catheter. Initially when I was out and about I had constant leakage and never had any urine to pass if I walked very far and my bladder was empty when I got to a bathroom. About 7 guards or shields a day. Most nights dry. Able to hold urine now with a few drips and spurts walking, but have urine in my bladder when I use the restroom. Down to 5 guards or shields a day, but much more active and consuming more liquids. Doing Ks at least 3x a day, but not doing them standing up was an early mistake. URO says things will be slow to improve first 6 weeks.

Posts.Title: Gleason score of 9... what can we expect?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Busby, you are a young man and your pathology was not that bad. It appears from your sig that the cause of your PSA is your positive margin and lymphoascular invasion. So there is likely some cancerous tissue remaining local to your prostate bed. My non-professional recommendation would be to treat it NOW before it leaves the pelvic area and moves on to other parts of your body. At that point it would become incurable, and you would be destined for lifelong HT, or a slow painful death. You are much too young for that. Hit this thing with everything available NOW to knock it out before it takes over. Good luck! You make some valid points and I do not advocate no treatment, but with the LVI is there is a reasonable possibility that things are not still regional. Going through RT with possible zero benefit will likely be the recommended treatment.

Posts.Title: PSA 5 weeks after RALP - Good News

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Trex Dino Quick introduction: Biopsy week ago, results 24 hours ago. Everything is a bit of a blur and working on getting a handle of things today. Researching, ordering books, making doc appointments, scheduling bone and CT scans as well as adding my five-year colonoscopy follow-up. Found this forum today and just signed up. Biopsy diagnosis: 13 samples, (6) Gleason score 7, (2) Gleason score 8, (4) Gleason score 9 and (1) suspicious. Staging is 3. CT in 2016 (little blood and stones due to dehydration working outside in extreme heat) and MRI Dec 2018 show prostate normal size with no enlargement (comparing the 2016 CT to the 2018 MRI). PSA Nov 2018 7.1 Prescribed Proscar and Flomax PSA Dec 2018 4.1 (PSA drop due to Proscar ?) Yesterday, off of Proscar and Flomax. Age 63. Still coming to terms with all this. Sorry about your DX. I joined here a few weeks ago. Be patient as best you can the medical wheels move very slowly and the answers you want people will not be able to answer. The more you search the internet the more contradictory data may become. As I am not far in front of you in this process, eating and hydrating properly can be a challange and an afternoon nap helps a lot with the emotional anxiety. I have also noticed that minor aches and pains I used to ignor emotionally drag me down. Ibuprofen is a big help. If they have not told you, you are High risk. Now is a good time to decide if you are going to a cancer center of excellence or staying with who you have. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What Do You Do When Your 2nd Opinion Is Different From Your First

Posts.Content: According to the folks at Decipher, “The data demonstrates that patients with high PORTOS scores treated with radiotherapy had a lower incidence of distant metastasis at 10 years than patients with high PORTOS scores who did not receive radiotherapy, suggesting that treatment with postoperative radiotherapy should be considered for patients in this subgroup. Conversely, patients with low PORTOS scores had similar outcomes whether or not they received postoperative radiotherapy.” But ADT is never curative. So the question is do you take a chance or throw in the towel?

Posts.Title: What Do You Do When Your 2nd Opinion Is Different From Your First

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Mags, While the second PSA reading is a big jump, make certain you get at least one, if not two, confirmatory readings. Did you doc suggest a repeat PSA in 30 days? That is often done because it is fairly soon after the troubling report, but long enough that, if the PSA is indeed rising, it may come back even a bit higher than the last. Or it might shed light on an erroneous reading. While the main negative finding was EPE, it was focal and not extensive; and there was also LVI+. By themselves I think you could safely wait to see if the PSA plateaus at a non-threatening value. But coupled with a high Decipher score, I can see the reason for concern. The Decipher test itself is being used as one factor in decision-making. Studies have validated it. But do note that it provides two risks/probabilities, not guarantees of anything. Note that the Average risk range is 0.45--6.0, so your husband's score is just high enough to put him in the High-Risk group. In other words, your husband's risk for metastases might be just a faction higher than someone with a Decipher score at the top of the Average-risk category. You may want to discuss that point at your next visit. You should note that the GRID report is provided to doctors for "research purposes" and it is stated by GenomeDx that it is not for clinical decision-making. In my GRID, it said my cancer's theoretical response to ADT is a terrible 1 on a scale of 0 to 100, 100 being best. When I pointed this out to my uro/surgeon, he said, that while he was told and reads that about 10% of men have no initial response to HT, he has never had a patient that didn't have some response, at least initially. And he, too, pointed out that the GRID has not been clinically validated like the Decipher has been. That said, I'm not understanding fully why a post-op radiation response would be that low. We know that some men have recurrence after RT as their primary treatment. It's possible that this is what the low score is reflecting, but I don't know for certain. Have you discussed the possibility of a RT+ADT combo? A suggestion: call GenomeDx and say you are possibly facing post-RP treatment and ask to speak to someone about the Decipher and GRID results you received. The company was good about answering my email questions. My take-away is use Decipher as an additional factor; but I would rely on my doc's experience over the GRID report. I don't know if the GRID report is provided unless it is requested. I was under the impression that most men didn't see theirs. I hope that helps, Djin One element I see folks fixed on is a rise in PSA is likely from PCa in the prostate bed. The D report could be reflecting systemic spread that radiation isn’t going to touch.

Posts.Title: How much faith does everyone put in Decipher and Grid results?

Posts.Content: According to the folks at Decipher, “The data demonstrates that patients with high PORTOS scores treated with radiotherapy had a lower incidence of distant metastasis at 10 years than patients with high PORTOS scores who did not receive radiotherapy, suggesting that treatment with postoperative radiotherapy should be considered for patients in this subgroup. Conversely, patients with low PORTOS scores had similar outcomes whether or not they received postoperative radiotherapy.” But ADT is never curative. So the question is do you take a chance or throw in the towel?

Posts.Title: How much faith does everyone put in Decipher and Grid results?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I've always wondered about this for my own case. My Gleason 6 was organ confined (with a small PM) and PSA has been zero since the surgery in 2011. And, knowing that Gleason 6 cannot metastasize, makes me wonder if this low risk form of the disease -- after apparently being cured -- is also risk-free if taking testosterone treatments. The odds that a very small amount of Gleason 7 was missed during pathology, one of those cell floated into the blood stream, and some extra T was enough to jump start it is low, but that is a risk I wouldn’t take.

Posts.Title: Testosterone after prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouragement. The reason for the early test is I have been experiencing hip pain for about 2 years prior to DX and always believed it was arthritis, but now not so sure. .3 the maximum value stated by my URO for 30 days so I was hoping for a lower value. Keep in mind my PCa was a low PSA producer from the beginning. Will have another test in 30 days. Decipher test was ordered and will be doing ART in 5 months. Decision on ADT to be made based on D-score. Honestly believe the chance a cure is rather slim at this point.
Posts.Title: Post surgery PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IceStationZebra I have a coworker...staff member actually. We talked about prostate issues previously and he said he had issues and was taking flowmax. So I figured he was in good care. He told me two days ago that his GP had told him his prostate had grown since the last exam. He apparently wasnt regularly seeing the urologist. I asked what the GP said or did, he doubled his flowmax. What the heck? The GP has watched his PSA in the high 3s for years and said nothing. So I asked him what his urologist said at the last visit and he said he told me you dont have prostate cancer, dont worry. So he stopped going. That might not sound that terribly bad until you realize the poor guy is 42 or 43 years old. African American. His PSA has been in the upper 3s for years. It was 3.7 at last years check. Oh yeah and no family history unless you count both his dad and his uncle on his fathers side who had prostate cancer. Oh and the urologist proclaimed he didnt have cancer without doing free PSA, pca3, 4K, an MRI or a BIOPSY. For the love of all thats good and holy...hes been failed by both doctors in a very bad way. How can that urologist even make that comment with no factual testing basis? I sat him down and explained the things I could and gave him a roadmap of what Ive done and been through. I tried to impart the gravity of what he could be facing without terrifying him, but hes motivated now. I gave him my doctors name but warned him about the office staff. He needs some immediate help and a biopsy. What is wrong with these doctors? While I agree your co-worker needs a Uro, assuming the PSA is or is not cancer with values in the 3s is not a valid. Heck, I have a PSA of 5.11 and I know a high number of people my age with higher values seeing their URO with no biopsy. 90% of the biopsies come back negative. Because there is no cancer, BPH,and the needles missing the lesions when there is. That is what ISO PSA test is supposed to due - eliminate unneeded biopsies.

Posts.Content: Is the pathology completed and you are just waiting on the appointment for the results? If so, I’d walk into the URO office and ask for a copy. With that said, if were real bad they would be scheduling you for a CT and bone scan now.

Posts.Title: MRI and endorectal coil

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmwierz45 Group, Got my 3 month uPSA results last week, and as it was at 6 weeks, my uPSA is 0.01 Yay! It was a good news/bad news week, though. I also got my Decipher results, and they came in at 0.76. Inasmuch as my Gleason group was a 5 pre-op, and a 4 post-up, and there being a couple other physiological high-risk factors I have, such as extra prostatic extension, it's looking more likely that adjuvant radiation will be in my future in a couple months. How prevalent are the side effects of radiation, and what do the worst case scenarios look like? I Thanks. Your data brings up a question. My path report says 90-95% grade 4 w/ cribriform. Is it possible to get a decipher score with a low value with that pathology? Seems this test for grades 4 and 5 would not be a game changer for anyone.

Age.Phrase: I get $ at age 62 and $$ at 65  and

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I am not trying to sway your treatment decisions, but one question you might want to ask about is incontinence after surgery. My URO advised me the big abdomens put stress on the bladder and cause long tern incontinence that may require additional surgery....Met with Dr Kaouk at Cleveland Clinic for preop today. Palpation suggest no prostate adhesions and he will be performing a single incision RALP Monday outpatient....My URO advised me the big abdomens put stress on the bladder and cause long tern incontinence that may require additional surgery. I also have an acquaintance who is GS8 who had a very good outcome with Cryotherapy....
